note: For the Hippocratic writings on exercise and regimen, see Jouanna 1999, especially 166–168, 324–325 and 408–409.
title: for a useful overview of the development of athletic training in Classical Greek, and especially Athenian culture, up to the fourth century bce, but with mention of Hellenistic and Roman evidence too; also brief discussions in Pritchard 2003, especially 302–306, and Kyle 1987, especially 141–145: all three include useful surveys of key Platonic passages

note: Fortenbaugh, Sharples, and Sollenberger 2002 for translation of Theophrastus’ works on sweat and fatigue.
title: For a survey of the educational and other functions of the gymnasium in the Greek cities of the Hellenistic period

On the Hellenistic fragments see (in German) Wöhrle 1990, 158–183, part of a broad survey of ancient traditions of writing about regimen/dietetics/preservative healthcare from Homer to Galen; also van der Eijk 2000–2001, especially 1.293–331 for translations of the most relevant fragments of Diocles

note: For translations of Galen into English, Singer 1997 for Protrepticus, On Good Condition, Thrasybulus, and On Exercise with the Small Ball; and Green 1951 for De Sanitate tuenda.
title: surveys the key works in turn; also Smith 1979, 106–114 on Galen’s opportunistic use of the Hippocratic heritage in De Sanitate tuenda and the Thrasybulus; van der Eijk 2008, 297–300 for useful brief introduction to Galen’s approach to preservative medicine in De Sanitate tuenda and elsewhere; and Wöhrle 1990, 213–248 for a more detailed account
For Philostratus’ Gymnasticus, König 2005, 301–344, surveys the epigraphical evidence for trainers in the Roman Empire; also König and Rusten
for further analysis and contextualization. Also crucial is Jüthner’s commentary (in German) 1909, including 3–131 for a long survey of earlier writing on regimen

Other useful studies include Potter 2011, 137–168, who offers a vivid survey of what we know about trainers and training methods, with particular reference to Galen and Philostratus; and Golden 2008, 1–39, who focuses especially on the social status of trainers and their athletes
